review_headline: Lots of surprises in 5 discs of wonderful compositions!
review_body:
You’d be hard pressed to think of anyone who’s done more to promote contemporary piano composition, particularly that in the “minimalist” vein, than the Dutch performer, Jeroen Van Veen. His protean efforts have yielded a wide range of voluminous recordings, all expertly performed in an exciting range of styles.

It’s not surprising, then, that he’s used his encyclopedic knowledge to also create a 5-disc offering of his own compositions, all excellent and the whole collection a listening delight. While it’s hard to briefly comment on so many CD’s, suffice it to say that the first three discs are openly minimalist in their origins and are hypnotic in their appeal, some cuts meditative while others will want to make you get up and dance (yes, I did). The range is delicious, including some engaging uses of prepared pianos, carillon, tape and organ. The fourth disc takes off in some unexpected directions, including a fascinating essay on the four elements and one of my favorites, “Repeating History,” a thrilling mash-up of fragments of classical compositions to which minimalist music is indebted, knowingly or not, and all knitted together seamlessly with Van Veen’s compositional threads. The last CD is NLXL, inspired by the aerial photography of Holland by Karel Tomei. There’s a great video (viewable on YouTube) of Van Veen and his wife, Sandra, performing it with huge projections of the photos behind them. I find this format more effective for the piece and while the Van Veens use a wide range of interesting techniques to accompany their two pianos (including ambient sounds), some themes overstay their welcome a bit for me without the visuals.

So, a LOT of music to enjoy from a composer/performer of great passions and a lively imagination. Definitely worth exploring!

17. Slim Whitman. Tumbling Tumbleweeds. Again see Kitty Wells.
18. Glen Campbell. Rhinestone Cowboy. Classic 1970s Country/Pop at it's best.

review_headline: Real music from real rock stars!
review_body: There's no question that these guys are the real deal.  But let me open a can of worms by saying, "why buy this or any music when you can stream it on Prime or Spotify?  Not that I don't support the purchase of music - I do - wholeheartedly in fact.  But the music business has devalued music to such an extent that we can now play any and all music whenever we want - and not just on our phones but in our living rooms through our great stereo systems.  Maybe they aren't on our hard drives or in our CD players (and who uses one of those these days?) but my point being that the artists make less than $.003 cents per play from streaming.  So let's put that in perspective - 100,000 paid downloads puts about $50K in the pockets of the artist or label.  That same number of streams puts $300 in their pockets.  You read that right!  $300.00!  Who the hell can survive on that kind of income???  So how and why have we, the music buying public, allowed this to happen knowing that soon all we'll have to listen to is music that "was" made and not much that is new?  The only bands/artists that will survive are those who can tour and fill stadiums while basically giving away their music as a loss leader to get you to buy tickets to their shows.  Do you know how many artists will be driven from this business simply because they don't fit that mold?  Try 95%!  We have devalued music to such an extent that it's basically now free.  And so marks the end of the music business, the end of great music, the end of distribution and labels.  Technology killed the rock star!  And we are letting it happen.  Well done world!

This astonishing set was recorded by Decca in Detroit, in May of 1979, with Antal Doráti, KBE, conducting. Hugo von Hofmannsthal's libretto, après the ancient Greek dramatists, approaches the bizarre, for which Richard Strauss composed some of his most intricate music; the orchestration of "Die ägyptische Helena" (1928) is undeniably brilliant, even according to the exalted standard of this composer.

The cast is headed by Dame Gwyneth Jones, Matti Kastu, and Barbara Hendricks. Miss Hendricks had one of the most beautiful voices before the public. Not so, the controversial Dame Gwyneth: Her singing was wild, off-pitch, harsh, and sometimes otherwise approximate. Nevertheless, she was one of the towering singing-actresses of the last century. As the legendarily-beautiful Helen of Troy, the soprano gives us one of her most disciplined studio recordings, and, as one can see from the cover photograph of her by Christian Steiner, Dame Gwyneth is a great beauty in her own right. She is both precise and greatly exciting in this underrated score.

The Finnish Heldentenor Kastu is excellent in a very demanding rôle. Also in the cast is the distinguished Sir Willard White, and this is certainly one of the finest entries in Doráti's extensive discography.

review_headline: Up it by a half-star if you put it on shuffle play.
review_body:
A solid collection of tracks assembled from a series of 10" singles dating between 2012-2015.

The six 10" EPs themselves each contained one new A-side, one new cover tune, and one reworking of a song from Crenshaw's back catalogue. The compilation contains only the six A-sides and six cover tunes, and none of the reworkings. Also included is a bonus live track and a bonus demo dating back to sometime in the 90s.

The new songs are all in Marshall's later mode: mid-tempo, sometimes downbeat, often with a wryly reflective point of view. As well, the well-scrubbed pop hooks of thirty years ago are now much more subtle, and may take a few spins to sink in. Unfortunately, the album isn't well served by putting all six of these originals back-to-back to lead off the album, as the tone of each of these six songs is somewhat similar, and it makes the album seem more monochromatic than it actually is.

The seven covers (including the live bonus track) are a little more stylistically diverse, ranging from some rock-oriented Everly Brothers material to an achingly sincere "Close To You".

Overall, there's nothing absolutely revelatory about #392, but the album is still chock full of good songcraft performed with skill and passion. If you're a long-term Crenshaw fan, this is a worthwhile purchase. But if you're just getting in to Mr. Crenshaw's work? I would say that there are other albums (Downtown, Life's Too Short, Marshall Crenshaw) that show him to greater advantage -- explore those ones first.

product_title: Feat Kenny Burrell - Mess of Blues
review_body:
I have owned this album for over five years, and also own the source albums. This is an odd mix, but all tracks feature Johnny Hodges and Kenny Burrell.

Here are the albums that comprise this set:
Tracks 1 through 7 is the album titled [[ASIN:B004114U5K Mess of Blues LP]] that was recorded for Verve in NYC on September 4, 1963. The music is more on the mellow side with beautiful guitar lines from Burrell and those beautiful B3 notes from Davis with a wonderful combination of sustained and staccato notes. The drummer is Ed Shaughnessy who plays with taste and is a perfect fit for this ensemble. Of course, Hodges' trademark alto sax is the centerpiece of each track.

Tracks 8 through 10 are from that album titled [[ASIN:B00Q50W5ZC Johnny Hodges & Wild Bill Davis Blue Rabbit]] that was originally recorded for Verve in NYC spanning two 1963 and two 1964 sessions. These tracks are from 1963. May 15, 1963 features Hodges on alto, Ray Jackson on organ, Kenny Burrell on guitar, Wendell Marshall on bass and Bobby Donaldson on drums for I Let A Song Go Out Of My Heart and Tangerine. On May 17, for the song Creole Love Call the same line-up performs, except Jack Lesberg is the bassist.

The remaining tracks are the album titled [[ASIN:B0002ZEWPM Stride Right]] that was recorded for Verve in NYC on January 14, 1966. The line-up is Hodges on alto, Earl Hines on piano and a rhythm section that includes Kenny Burrell on guitar (who adds a LOT), Richard Davis on bass and Joe Marshall on drums.
Listened to it again after years. Still a masterpiece.

review_body:
I can't add much to the first review except to say that Pandolfo speaks of the importance for performers of not losing sight of their "feral musicality". Feral is a pretty strong word, Pandolfo has it in spades, and despite the Germanic emotional restraint in this music, there's no mistaking it here. Ranging from gossamer delicacy (Andante BWV 1027) to fiercely fast ornamentation (Allegro, BWV 1028) to a wonderful sense of tumbling pell mell onto home base (same movement, BWV 1028), there is a strong sense of something wild in his perfomance.

Add to that the perfect communication between him and Hünninger, picking up on each other's declamation and ornamentation, the clear un-French-ness, and the top notch balance (helpfully engineered, I suspect, in the studio) between them, and the joys of this release are myriad.

product_title: Carl Nielsen: The Symphonies & Concertos [Box Set]
review_headline: Actually, not a bad set overall...concertos better than the symphonies
review_body:
After hearing, and not much liking, Gilbert's performance of "The Four Temperaments," I was pleasant surprised when listening to this complete set. Yes, "The Four Temperaments" (and "The Inextinguishable") are rather underdone, but they're simply bursting with energy when compared to Sakari Oramo's new recordings on the Bis label. I still prefer Douglas Bostock to Gilbert overall in the complete symphonies, but when hearing all six Gilbert does have his moments. Overall, however, the performances I turn to the most often are Herbert Blomstedt's magnificent (second) Nielsen cycle on Decca with the San Francisco Symphony.

Where Gilbert really does shine is in his conducting of the concertos. Here, it seems that he really comes to life, and by and large he has soloists who are superior to those that Bostock used. Thus, if you want a complete set of all the symphonies and concertos by one conductor and don't really case if the symphony performances aren't the best, this is an OK set...certainly better as a whole than I would have expected.

No one is superior at exploring, salvaging and polishing sunken jazz treasures in the deep sea than George Klabin and Zev Feldman. “In The Beginning,” packed with thick booklet of rich information and rare photographs together with lavish memorabilia as usually, takes you in the sweaty, hard-drinking crowd in the Turf Club in Indianapolis by traveling beyond the space-time. Quincy Jones’ comment, “I can hear greatness sometimes before the musicians themselves know they have it,” expresses all about this package. Even at the Spire session, seven years before the Turf Club dates, Wes had filled in allotted small spaces with his unique thumb plucking single-tone. Wes, as-yet undiscovered, is genuinely enjoying his play with friends getting along well in his daily milieu. You won’t discern Wes’s signature orchestration of solo yet in this Turf Club live, that is opening with single note choruses before unleashing choruses of octaves and finalizing with choruses of cords. His solo is a single note burn of the highest order, imaginative and joyful, which is all purely hard-bop-inspired.

His tone is distinguishably warm, his phrasing is uncannily fluid, and above all, his tempo is blazingly fast. Listen to Wes’s guitar with stunning speed in “Brazil,” “My Heart Stood Still,” and “Caravan.” Wes supports Pookie Johnson’s ideas with his tender solo. Blowing chord melodies on “Caravan,” and “Six Bridges To Cross” is a foretell of things to come. It is simmering, steaming with confidence and force. Much more striking fact is the consistency with his play throughout the album. “I Should Care,” where other band members lay out, is truly fascinating. Restful guitar sound is nicely matching with Andrews’ firm voicing. On “Ralph’s New Blues” Wes takes up a bass. Buddy’s episode of soothing Wes, who complains of rope-like thickness of bass strings, is heartwarming. Buddy said, “do something good at least you can take it.” Only an elder person within a family could say like this. As a result, Wes left us a good walking bass solo.

Three tracks from the Missile Lounge on Oct. 22. ’58, make us easily imagine Cannonball Adderley’s and Orrin Keepnews’ excitement when they hear their play at the first time eleven months later. A photographer Duncan Schiedt vividly reports witnessing these historical moments in the inserted booklet. “Soft Winds” is a rare recording to capture Melvin Rhyne playing a piano. Wes is galloping with octaves up and down following his single-note solo on “Soft Winds.” A chase with Richie Crabtree is fantastic. On “Robbin’s Nest,” he is heading into choruses of slick octave work and then finishing off his solo with brilliant chord soloing. Buddy Montgomery confirms to Joseph Woodard in the same booklet that guitar as a lead, melodic instrument was a new idea and unusual sound at that time. They played basically bebop.

As to his four compositions collected in this album, “Leila,” “Far Wes,” and “Wes’ Tune” are recorded again for “Montgomeryland (Pacific, ’58,)” which are compiled and re-issued as “Bigginings (BN-LA531-H2)” from Blue Note. For “Leila,” I take this columbia version, which features Buddy’s precise piano solo. A pacific version of “Far Wes” is extended to nearly double length of this columbia version. A pacific version provides fairly spaces for Harold Land and Buddy after Wes. They all perform emotionally imaginative play. I choose a pacific version for these solo. “Wes’ Tune” is compactly rearranged in a pacific version. However, I prefer an enthusiastic play at the Turf Club. The fourth composition “Blues” is very close with the title tune of “Movin’ Wes (Verve, ’64.)” Wes might developed a concept of this tune into “Movin’ Wes” later.

review_headline: A delightful early album from Owl City -- whimsical, soothing, and fun
review_body:
I was first introduced to Owl City by way of my brother, who has a knack for finding offbeat but wonderful musicians to follow. I was further intrigued when Owl City's hit song "Fireflies" became popular (and was sampled in one of "Weird Al" Yankovic's polka medleys -- I end up liking a lot of songs due to Al's influence...). To call Owl City a "band" is a bit of a misnomer, as it's mostly one guy and a synthesizer -- "music project" is the term most people use -- but all the same I was delighted to discover that Adam Young's music didn't adhere to the standards of modern pop music, nor was it the harsh and repetitive stuff people come to expect from electronic acts such as Daft Punk. It's unique, delightful, and both lively and soothing to the ear.

"Maybe I'm Dreaming" is Owl City's first album, and it has a unique and whimsical sound to it that I love. And while his more recent hits, such as "Fireflies," "Good Time," and "When Can I See You Again?" might be more popular, it's hard to match the charm of his early album.

"Maybe I'm Dreaming" is an example of Owl City's music before it became influenced by popular artists (and before Adam Young would begin incorporating guest stars). His music feels almost like it comes out of one of Nintendo's video games -- electronic but light and playful, hitting a nice balance between soothing and lively. And his lyrics, while puzzling and even nonsensical at times, are clever and equally playful, painting fantastic dreamscapes for the listener. Though if you listen closely there are some odd and even shocking lyrics, such as "colors in my veins" and "smell of the crime scenes." Um... what?

It's difficult to pick a favorite song from this collection, but "On the Wing," "Sky Diver," and "West Coast Friendship" are strong contenders. All are beautifully done, with fun and playful lyrics that paint vivid pictures. "Sky Diver" is perhaps the most straightforward one of these, a simple song about a skydiver's experience leaping from a plane, though "West Coast Friendship" is pretty obviously about a man's journey to California to visit friends. Whether the lyrics are straightforward or obtuse, however, they're still a joy to listen to.

The only song on the album I didn't enjoy was "Dear Vienna," which has some harsher, almost industrial-sounding effects in the music that jarred me out of the song. I applaud Young for experimenting and trying out something different, but I didn't like this song as well, and it's probably my least favorite from the album.

A delightful first album from a favorite musician, "Maybe I'm Dreaming" is a great album for easy listening, and if you like electronic music, video game music, or just something pleasing to the ear, I highly recommend it. It's also a good example of Owl City's early work, before Adam Young became popular and started drifting more toward a mainstream sound.lyrics that paint vivid pictures. review_headline: Louis Lortie’s delightful traversal of Chopin’s waltzes
review_body:
Louis Lortie is evidently a Chopin aficionado. His tender approach and light finger-work, combined with a heartfelt insight, constitute the ingredients of memorable interpretations as testified in the previous three volumes of this series plus the benchmark recording of the 24 Preludes. Here, the French-Canadian virtuoso offers a spectacular, witty and graceful traversal of waltzes added with a few nocturnes, all played on that marvellous Fazioli piano.

This is a recording to listen to, time and again without getting bored. One can very simply tell why: the inspiration of a great pianist of today meets seductively and compellingly the confessions committed the beloved instrument by a great composer of the romantic era. Directness, simplicity, soaring and joy – these could be in short the main qualities of this recent release by Louis Lortie. Five stars!

review_headline: Sounds Like: Forbert meets early Springsteen
review_body:
I had never heard, or heard of, Marah before until I read a rave review of this album on a blog that I really like, so decided to give it a shot. The first time I listened to it I though it was Steve Forbert singing, especially the guy started playing the harmonica. More "Alive on Arrival" than "Jackrabbit Slim, but a definite Forbert vibe, unlike with unmistakable nod to Springsteen. But unlike Amazon's main editorial review, I don't hear "Nebraska" at all. Instead, many songs on this album have a distinct "Greetings from Asbury Park" sound to them. And as far as I'm concerned that's a very good thing!

Marah has taken those influences and rocked things up a few of the songs (people have used the Replacements for comparison, but I lean more toward the Hold Steady as kindred musical spirits) and the results are mostly very good. I wasn't blown away by all of the songs. "The Catfisherman", for example, sounds like a hackneyed attempt at being funky that just doesn't click. But when these songs DO click and fire, the melodies and energy are infectious. Overall, a most impressive album.

This recording would be of prime interest to classical music fans if only for the reason that it is one of the few recordings of any opera conducted by Reiner, and one of the very few recordings of a Wagner opera conducted by Reiner (see below). That the result is a superb realization of Wagner's marathon meditation on art and society makes it essential for those who appreciate Wagner and for classical music lovers in general.

The Vienna State Opera theater had been severely damaged late in World War II; the venerable venue didn't reopen until the autumn of 1955. This production of Die Meistersinger was a part of that festival. Because of the special nature of the occasion, the State Opera engaged the finest cast available and awarded the conducting duties to Fritz Reiner, who was molding the Chicago Symphony Orchestra into one of the world's great ensembles.

Paul Schoffler is heard here at the right time in his career for the role of Hans Sachs: he has the skill and insight of experience, while the voice is still strong and supple. There isn't any better Sachs on compact disc.

Hans Beirer's Walther does not offer silvery tones, but his energy and shaping of phrases make for an engaging performance.

The Eva of Irmgard Seefried might seem on the Gidget-y side early in the opera, but she matures fast and by the third act she projects a melting warmth.

Erich Kunz not only sings the role of Beckmesser splendidly, he manages to inject a smidgen of sympathetic feeling for the character.

The rest of the cast range from very good to better than that.

Fritz Reiner sensitively and firmly frames this sprawling musical canvas. From the nicely formed Prelude to the ensemble pieces, particularly the quintet in Act Three, he maintains a careful balance between the grand and the intimate. His attention to detail and his pacing reveal the riches in the score while keeping the drama flowing. If only Reiner had committed a Ring cycle to disc! (There is a recording of Reiner conducting the San Francisco Opera in the second act of Die Walkure taken from a radio broadcast, as this was. He was preparing Die Gotterdamerung for the Metropolitan Opera when he died in 1963).

I have an earlier release of this recording, on another label, so I'll refer to Robert Levine's review in Classics Today for a judgment of the sound quality here:
"The sound is Austrian Radio mono from 1955 but sounds 10 years younger–grand and able to cope with the big climaxes, clear in the ensembles, clean in quiet moments." To which I'll add: the listener must make allowances for this being a live recording — dynamics are variable as the performers move about the stage, etc. So, while this is not sonically sumptuous, it is good enough for the listener to enjoy a prime performance of a great opera.

Other recordings of Reiner conducting Wagner in full-length performances are: Tristan und Isolde at Covent Garden with Lauritz Melchior and Kirsten Flagstad on various labels, the Naxos release probably having the best sound [[ASIN:B00004YYQL Tristan & Isolde]]. Tristan und Isolde at the Met with Ramon Vinay and Helen Traubel [[ASIN:B0030AEPY4 Richard Wagner: Tristan Und Isolde (Tristan and Isolde) [New York -- December 9, 1950: Helen Traubel, Blanche Thebom, Ramon Vinay, Sven Nilsson, Paul Schoeffler (Schoffler), Hugh Thompson, Leslie Chabay, Thomas Hayward, Lawrence Davidson; Fritz Reiner]]]. Der Fliegende Holländer at the Met with Hans Hotter, available as part of a box set of Wagner at the Met [[ASIN:B00AL6SM0S Wagner at the Met: Legendary Performances from The Metropolitan Opera]]

US released May 2001 – "Tell Mama: The Complete Muscle Shoals Recordings" by ETTA JAMES on Universal/MCA/Chess 088 112 518-2 (Barcode 008811251826) is a 22-track CD compilation and plays out as follows (57:09 minutes):

Tracks 1 to 12 are the LP "Tell Mama" – released January 1968 in the USA on Cadet LP 802 (Mono) and Cadet LPS 802 (Stereo). Although the "Tell Mama" album was released in supposed 'Stereo' – Universal's tape research shows that true stereo mixes for Tracks 2, 3, 4, 5 and 10 were never made - fake Stereo was used on the issued LP - so they've been replaced here with the true Mono mixes. Bearing that in mind - Tracks 1, 6, 7, 8, 9, 11 and 12 are in STEREO – Tracks 2, 3, 4, 5 and 10 are in MONO.

BONUS TRACKS (all in Mono, only Mono Masters exist):

The four-way foldout inlay has new liner notes by LEE HILDEBRAND (it also reproduces the original Morry Roth LP liner notes) as well as track-by-track annotation. There are colour photos of Etta in the Studio with the seated horn section of James Mitchell, Charles Chalmers and Floyd Newman - another with the rest of the band – Calvin Scott, Billy Foster, Jimmy Ray Johnson and Albert Lowe, Jr. – and a final shot of an smiling Gene "Bowlegs" Miller with Producer and owner of Fames Studios – Rick Hall. It’s nicely done if not a tiny bit slight – but that cannot be said of the fabulous ERICK LABSON remasters. Labson has handled as many as 1000 remasters overt the decades including the vast majority of the huge Chess Records catalogue as well as prestigious Rock catalogues like Steppenwolf, Three Dog Night, Neil Diamond, Wishbone Ash and The Who (to name but a few). But his work here is gorgeous – especially on those stunning Stereo cuts.

The LP is very much a product of the 60tsR&B times – fast-slow, fast-slow and so on. A fast belter opens proceedings with the Stereo take of "Tell Mama" putting hairs on your chest – which is followed by the magnificent ache of "I'd Rather Go Blind" (Christine McVie would almost make the song her own with Chicken Shack on Blue Horizon who covered it that year). Etta doesn't appreciate her jealous lover in "Watch Dog" as she tells us "...I don't want no man of mine everywhere I go...he's right behind...he's like the FBI!” You on the other hand will love this groovy shimmy and shake dancer penned by Don Covay. Time for Ed Townshend's "The Love Of My Man" where Etta tells us he's the greatest chap in the whole wide world. Shortly after she’s telling us in uncomfortable sucker-mode that even though 'he beat on me and he cheat on me' her man's ok really because in private he can be so sweet (what a guy).

The chipper Lloyd Webster/Leonard Caston number "The Same Rope" advises that if Etta's man leaves he maybe using that rope to hang himself when he realises what he's done (stunning audio on this especially in the rhythm section). She does a great job with Otis Redding's "Security" and the sexy arrangement she gives Jimmy Hughes' "Steal Away" is refreshing while still retaining the brilliance of that wicked original. Etta has a family itch she needs to scratch in the cautionary "My Mother In Law" where she tells us that she's "...Sick and tired of your mother...always sticking her nose in my business...seems like I married her...instead of you..." (oh dear). And on it goes to her slinky cover of Rosco Gordon's "Just A Little Bit" - a wicked hip-wiggler bound to put your arteritis out to pasture...

The 10 bonus tracks offer three Previously Unreleased (18, 19 and 22) while her single-only cover of Sonny & Cher's "I Got You Babe" is Previously Unreleased on album. Unfortunately it's easy to hear why her cover of "Misty" was canned – its jazzy arrangement feels dated, out of place and just doesn’t suit her. Better is the boogie of "You Took It", the Don Covay dancer "You Got It" and the chugging Clarence Carter funk of Willie Dixon's "Fire".

A wicked CD Reissue currently retailing at just over three quid from certain sellers. "I'm on fire! I'm hot!" Etta assures us on the funky R&B winner "Fire"...and I think she’s right...

It alsmost seems foolish to write a review for an album that is SO essential, one you really need to own (and most of the people reading this probably own it anyway). It's a transitional album, the sound of the Brian Jones Stones making way for the Mick Taylor Stones. Jones and Taylor each play relatively minor roles here. Even Taylor's "baptism by fire," throwing him into the deep end of the pool for the live set "Get Yer Ya-Ya's Out," has been dwarfed by later live archive stuff like the "Official Bootleg" of "The Brussels Affair" as well as the Leeds, Marquee and Roundhouse concerts accompanying the "deluxe" reissue of "Stick Fingers." That's where the new band was fully formed, where it became a great, howling, ferocious behemoth unequalled in the history of rock & roll. Consider the famous boast that opens "Ya Ya's"..."The GREATEST rock & roll band in the world, The Rolling Stones..." It's true, you know? The Beatles were a cultural phenomenon that could hardly be contained by the label of "rock band." The Who were a force of nature, but they were never an "everyman" band unless you felt comfortable inside of Pete Townshend's head, dancing with his demons. No, it was and will always be The Stones...Keef, churning out precise, deliberate machine gun blasts of Chuck Berry riffs, Charlie holding it all together with his trademark bemused / bored stiff expression, Jagger and that rooster strut. I don't think the band fully knew where they were going during the "Let It Bleed" sessions. It was an exploration, a search for something bigger and bolder than what they had in the moment, even though they were kings of their particular hill. Compare "With The Beatles" and "Revolver"...same thing. "Let It Bleed" and what follwed was NOT "better than" anything from the Brian Jones prime years. It was different. It was a band evolving.

Obviously,"Gimme Shelter," "Love In Vain," "Midnight Rambler," and "You Can't Always Get What You Want" went on to become "concert staples," with the "Ya Ya's" version of "Rambler" becoming "definitive," but as I said above, maybe left in the dust by some of the tougher performances from the Taylor era that finally saw the light of day.

For my tastes, Johnny Winter took ownershiop of the title track on his "Still Alive And Well" album. He just tapped a vein of sarcasm, ennui, humor, just SOMETHING that Mick & Keith glossed over by comparison.

"You Got The Silver" finally saw a well-deserved rebirth in the "Shine a Light" film, and "Monkey Man" has been trotted out on stage a few times, too.

There are NO "disposable" tracks on this one. All nine, all 43 minutes worth, this is as good as it gets. It's history that still rocks, still moves, still inspires.

It's as essential as it gets, so...what are ya waiting for? If you own it, go listen to it, and if you don't, get it now.

product_title: Beethoven: Complete Piano Sonatas (Dino Ciani Rediscovered)
review_body:
Like so many others," Dino Ciani came to grief behind a steering-wheel. He had been hailed as \\""miraculously gifted . . . one of the most remarkable examples of the rarest talents one could hope to find\\"" by Cortot (his teacher) and had worked with the likes of Abbado", Muti, Barbirolli, Guilini and Gui before that fateful day in March 1974. Great expectations were confounded therein.

This entire cycle was recorded over a period of a few weeks in the spring of 1970 in Torino. Dynamic's liner notes state that a tape recorder was stationed in the centre of the hall for the live recordings. In consequence," one hears the audience down to the last sniffle. \\""The piano is distant and can ring", bite, glare, and grate all at the same time. There's pitch distortion, wow, drop-outs," overloading.\\"" Name the malady - it's there. On my part"," I soon acclimatised to it. It sounds too atmospheric to be Plain Jane mono.

Todd on naim.audio.com has written a superlative review in depth which I am going to summarise shamelessly since I agree with his viewpoint. When Beethoven calls for the \\""fast and furious\\""", Ciani responds in spades (the Appassionata is quite something). His effortless technique and lyricism enliven the set and command attention. Alas, barnstorming technique prevails over thought in many instances (the Hammerklavier being a prime example, and Ciani has little to say in Opus 111 beyond mere notes). After a radiant opening to Opus 110, the pianist rushes his fences in the Allegro Molto that follows; boring it ain't but nor does it satisfy. Indeed, one could classify so many of these performances as being glorified sight-readings by a prodigy out to impress.

If you're interested in superheated, speed-demon Beethoven, played by a He-Man of the keyboard, this set is for you - provided you can accept that its philosophical ordnance is underbaked. Ciani was in his late Twenties at the time so one can regard them as transitional readings rather than the terminus that they became. Warts and all, I'd rather listen to James Dean's Beethoven than any number of cycles from the likes of Brendel and Barenboim in their spinster ways. If nothing else, you won't be bored.n the terminus that they became. Due to the increasing number of past heroes who make their come-backs, trying to re-live their past fame or to bring in some fresh bucks to pay the bills, I hesitated before picking up this album, bearing also in mind that his last attempt was not doing him any justice. But when I finally started listening to it, I was blown away.

I have listened to Billy Idol from almost the start, when Rebel Yell and lots of other smash hits were rocking the dance floors. However, as an album, "Whiplash smile" has been my favorite up until now. This album stands out from the others. Many albums have their "good ones" and the "not so good ones", but this is one of the few albums (regardless of artist) where I actually just let the entire album just run, and run, and run.. I am blown away of how he the a certain degree has updated to contemporary style while still applying a stronger Billy Idol signature than in a long time. I am actually surprised that lyrics and musicwise, we comes off as a more mature and humbled man, refreshingly honest about where he is in life and how he looks back. And at the same time he still keeps his integrity as a punk/rocker. This is not very easy to combine, but he actually pulls it off! -On every track! OK, some maybe better than others, but every track is more than good enough for me to listen to and enjoy. Some of the songs also amuse old fans with references to his old hits, and in particular "Postcards from the past" is entirely built on references to the past (thus the title). This is also something 9 out of 10 faded artists would want to try, but Billy Idol actually more than pulls it off, he really aced this song!

I rate this album his best ever as a complete album. It is a perfect come-back revenge, he is new, he is old, and very much alive. Introspective songs and a summary of the past, combined with refreshing rock music, starts off really cool, rocks a little bit, throws in some ballads that you believe, in contrast to many prior ones, and then the album rounds off with a fast, kick-ass punk/rock track to demonstrate the he still got it - and then he drops the mic! Noww, THAT's how you do it!! Thank you, Idol!

I hope not this is his last album, but if so, he did it in grace!

review_headline: Miles Live in Tokyo in 1975: Agharta/Pangea part 3
review_body:
This is not to be confused with the ‘Miles in Tokyo’ recording from the second great quintet’s tour of Japan in 1964. The music on this dual CD was recorded on 22 January 1975 at Shinjuku Kohseinenkin Hall in Tokyo, 10 days before the Agharta/Pangaea concerts in Osaka on 1st February. The Tokyo performance was originally recorded as an FM radio broadcast to be aired only in Japan, and includes different material to the Osaka concerts.

The band has the same line-up as Agharta/Pangea: Miles; two electric guitarists, Pete Cosey and Reggie Lucas; percussionist James Mtume Heath; young bass player Michael Henderson (who Miles stole from Stevie Wonder’s backing band!); Sonny Fortune on sax & flute, and drummer Al Foster.

If you like Agharta/Pangea, you’re going to like this: the band is in the same raunchy jazz/funk groove. Much of the performance is dominated by high-energy interplay between Cosey and Lucas, and Miles’ contributions to the sound are often played through a wah-wah pedal. Throughout Miles’ electric-fusion period 1969-75 no two performances were the same but each had structure, guided by Miles as band director as the music unfolds. As on Agharta/Pangea it’s obvious that this band knows its business, but no-one knew in advance when the changes would happen or where the music would go.

In a 2015 essay on Miles’ fusion/funk period, Angus Batey writes that the listener can best appreciate this music if s/he has “the ability to grasp the plan and understand the context for, and the nature of, these still shockingly futuristic and unequalled sounds…Miles and his 1975 band fusing jazz, rock and funk into a seamless, satisfying and richly rewarding whole”.

If you don’t know the Agharta/Pangea concerts but you do know ‘A Tribute to Jack Johnson’ and especially ‘Dark Magus’, you’re in essentially the same territory here. This is the raunchiest and funkiest territory in the vast continent of Miles Davis’ unequalled musical legacy. It’s regrettable that no-one is taking risks in exploring unknown musical landscapes like this in the 21st century.of Miles Davis’ unequalled musical legacy. review_headline: A 3-Star Collection For General Audiences - A Full 5 Stars For Specialty Collectors
review_body:
The fact this Collectables volume has sat around since 1996 without so much as one review is a clear indication of the obscurity of the late 1960s artists covered, all from the same general area in New Mexico, not to mention the local labels for which they recorded, in some cases just the one single. Needless to say, none of the sides ever made any kind of impact on the national singles charts, especially considering the lack of promotional funding by the labels.

So, as a collection, this will appeal more to the Pop music historian in general, or those collectors whose focus centres around artists calling New Mexico home, of which there were quite a few. For example, what you won’t see here is the instrumental group The King Pins (not the same gathering as that associated with King Curtis or the earlier 1960s group from Clarksdale, Mississippi) who recorded for yet another local label - Larse Records of Albuquerque - The Torques of Farmington, New Mexico who recorded for one of the labels involved here, Delta, and The Hooterville Trolley who cut sides for Lynette Records.

The most recorded band in this set is the surf-rock instrumental gathering King Richard & The Knights who, from 1961 to 1964, consisted of lead guitarist Dick Stewart, rhythm guitarist Larry Longmire, bassists Gary Butler (1961-1962) and Gary Snow (1963-1964), and percussionist/drummer William "Corky" Anderson. Personnel changes and the addition of vocalists from 1965 to 1967 saw the same titled band comprised of lead guitarist/vocalist Dick Stewart, percussionists/drummers Les Bigby and Jack Paden, rhythm guitarist John Milligan who was replaced at some point by Dick Miller, bassist Jerry "Toad" Hutchins, keyboardist Mike Celenze, and lead vocalist/saxophonist Larry Reid. Along the way they cut sides for Delta Records, set up in Albuquerque by the John Wagner Studios, as well as Red Feather and Jyck Records.

The band calling themselves The Plague cut their only single for the appropriately-named Epidemic Records (that was their only release as well), and consisted of former King Richards & The Knights drummer “Corky” Anderson along with Larry Shryock, Billy Main and Steve Erickson. Clearly, their “sound” was heavily influenced by the British Invasion band, The Kinks. Another group that recorded briefly for Delta was The Era Of Sound which included brothers Reynaldo and Michael Naranjo who also wrote both sides of their one release. Another one-release band were The Kreeg (guitarist/vocalist Robert J. Sturctman, lead guitarist Larry Ink, vocalist/bassist Hap Blackstock and drummer Russ Sturctman).

Compiled for Collectables by Michael Greisman, the full contents, showing artists, time lengths, label details and year of release, are: I Don’t Need You (1:52) - King Richard & The Knights - Delta 2143 - 1966; 2. How About Now? (2:40) - King Richard & The Knights - flipside of track 1; 3. Why? (2:39) - King Richard & The Knights - Delta 2115 - 1965; 4. That’s The Way It Goes (1:59) - King Richard & The Knights - flipside of track 3; 5. Go Away (1:56) - The Plague - Epidemic 2164 - 1967 (the flipside, Money, is not here); 6. The Girl In The Mini Skirt (2:54) - The Era Of Sound - Delta 2255 - 1968 (the flipside, Stay With Me, is not included); 7. Impressin’ (2:41) - The Kreeg - 1966 (the flipside, How Can I?, is omitted); 8. Tears From Laughing (2:28) - The Sidewinders - 1967; 9. review_headline: The Disturbed Masters of Metal Have Returned!!!!!
review_body:
I honestly thought I was dreaming when my #1 band of ALL TIME unveiled "Immortalized" and announced that their painfully long hiatus was over. Disturbed has been such an influence to me over the years. The first song I ever heard was "Ten Thousand Fists" and it was love at first sound. There something about David Draiman's voice was simply captivating, it was aggressive yet refined and I have always felt that his lyrics are written from the heart. I have closely followed Disturbed ever since, owning every album and listening to every song and never growing weary of any of them. Naturally, I was among the most depressed of their fans one they announced the hiatus 4 years ago. I pre-ordered the deluxe edition on day 1(after I had calmed down from the excitement of the album reveal.)

Disturbed's return is even better than I had dreamed it would be, and oh have I dreamed about when they would reignite the fury that, for a decade, they had carried so well. "Immortalized" feels like the logical sequel to Disturbed's last album, "Asylum" both lyrically and musically. However, I did notice that quite a few tracks here pay homage to all of their previous works( i.e. "Never Wrong" sounds like it is from "The Sickness" while "The Sound of Silence" sounds like it could be a b-side from "Believe"). I bet Disturbed did this on purpose and I am glad they did as they stayed true to their signature sound. I can't pick a favorite track off Immortalized because all 16(counting the 3 bonus tracks) are just beautifully composed, although I shall name a few highlights, "Never Wrong", "Legion of Monsters","You"re Mine", "Who Taught you how to Hate", "The Brave and the Bold", and "The Vengeful One."

P.S. I don't get why people are upset about the song "Fire it Up" I think that Disturbed was simply having fun when they wrote it(it is an awesome song).wesome song).

Even so, in some rare such cases there have been compilations emerge in CD format chronicling their efforts or, at the very least, multiple-artist compilations that included at least one of their sides. There is also usually some information available about them.

Then there are those who, despite actually hitting some national listings, have fallen through the cracks with absolutely NO personal details nor CDs containing any of their music. One such are The Profiles, allegedly from the St. Louis area. Not only do we not know their names, we don’t even know how many were involved with the group!

It would appear their first time on record came in 1966 with Musicland Records, a Minnesota label with distribution arrangements through the Amy-Mala-Bell concern - Windstorm (2:10) b/w Raindrops (2:13) as Musicland 20,004. A year later it seems they had the only release by the Louisville, Kentucky-based Big Russ Records - Cruelty In Motion (2:13) b/w You Can't Stop My Loving You (2:24) as Big Russ 4498.

None of those graced any national charts, but in Sept-Oct 1968 they had the André (Mr. Rhythm) Williams-produced If I Did’nt Love You (2:17) peak at # 30 R&B. And in case you’re wondering, that’s how “did’nt” was spelled on the label, which had Got To Be Your Lover (2:27) as the flipside of Duo 7749. I have no idea where that label was located (Chicago?).

But I do know that their next stop, Gene Chandler’s Bamboo Records, was in St. Louis and there they recorded Got To Be Love (Something Stupid) (2:46) which topped out at # 43 R&B in April-May 1969 b/w You Don’t Care About Me (2:55) as Bamboo 104. The follow-up I Still Love You (2:30) b/w Be Careful (3:00) as Bamboo 108 failed to chart in June. It also appears that Bamboo 115 later that year also carried the hit side, but this time titled Got To Be Love (Or Something Stupid) and with a time-length of 2:55. Whether that was just a re-mix or a different cut is not known, but the B-side on this release was A Little Misunderstanding (3:25).

So far, these widely scattered 45-rpm discs are the only source for anyone seeking their material, and when you listen to their efforts you will see that their talent deserved much greater commercial success.l-May 1969 b/w You Don’t Care About Me (2:55) as Bamboo 104. product_title: Frankenstein's Curse: Very Best of volume 4
review_headline: Phillip Glass, Frank Zappa, David Byrne, Tim Burton & Rob Zombie together? (no, but thats what this CD sounds like!)
review_body:
“Frankenstein’s Curse” by Michael D’Orazio is definitely NOT three chord pop! : Can you can picture a band with Phillip Glass, Frank Zappa, David Byrne, Tim Burton & Rob Zombie together? Are you IN to hear what that might sound like as an album? Then this is music created for you! The subtitle for this CD should be “Frankenstein’s Curse” - A Guided Journey to Hell and Back. (It is an INTENSE listen!) Important Tip: The 15 tracks (70 minutes) are best experienced as movements in an overall composition! Do yourself a favor and be immersed in the sound. You can DO other things just clear your ears to hear this loud and clear. It is not everyones cup of tea.. but if your still reading it is probably for you!
A roller coaster in a funhouse, with the first two tracks you are thrown right into hell’s Abyss. Instantly dragged into darkness, anger, madness, frustration and chaos. In each of the remaining 13 songs, there is a beautifully woven theme that is reprized through out the piece in the lyrics, concepts, rhythms and melodies. In between each ‘movement’ Its almost like, with a twinkle in his eye..silently, he says ‘What do you think of that?.. Well let me show you more...” and your off in a new direction. Acceptance, humor, whimsey, beauty, compassion, wisdom & exotic mystery, all dance with chaos and madness. The instrumentation and arrangements invoke sound sculptures that illustrate these many aspects of the journey through the pit, back and forth from 'disturbed' to 'normalcy' with flashes of genius. Being driven into madness by life, (a woman) is not a new theme. But with his unique perspective, the musical vision and talent of Michael D’Orazio make “Frankenstein’s Curse” telling of that story a great listen!

product_title: Precision: 60's Albuquerque Groups by Various Artists (1996-09-24)
review_headline: A 3-Star Offering For General Audiences - A Full 5 Stars For Specialty Collectors
review_body:
The fact this Collectables volume has sat around since 1996 without so much as one review is a clear indication of the obscurity of the late 1960s artists covered, all from the same general area in New Mexico, not to mention the local labels for which they recorded, in some cases just the one single. Needless to say, none of the sides ever made any kind of impact on the national singles charts, especially considering the lack of promotional funding by the labels.

So, as a collection, this will appeal more to the Pop music historian in general, or those collectors whose focus centres around artists calling New Mexico home, of which there were quite a few. For example, what you won’t see here is the instrumental group The King Pins (not the same gathering as that associated with King Curtis or the earlier 1960s group from Clarksdale, Mississippi) who recorded for yet another local label - Larse Records of Albuquerque - The Torques of Farmington, New Mexico who recorded for one of the labels involved here, Delta, and The Hooterville Trolley who cut sides for Lynette Records.

The most recorded band in this set is the surf-rock instrumental gathering King Richard & The Knights who, from 1961 to 1964, consisted of lead guitarist Dick Stewart, rhythm guitarist Larry Longmire, bassists Gary Butler (1961-1962) and Gary Snow (1963-1964), and percussionist/drummer William "Corky" Anderson. Personnel changes and the addition of vocalists from 1965 to 1967 saw the same titled band comprised of lead guitarist/vocalist Dick Stewart, percussionists/drummers Les Bigby and Jack Paden, rhythm guitarist John Milligan who was replaced at some point by Dick Miller, bassist Jerry "Toad" Hutchins, keyboardist Mike Celenze, and lead vocalist/saxophonist Larry Reid. Along the way they cut sides for Delta Records, set up in Albuquerque by the John Wagner Studios, as well as Red Feather and Jyck Records.

The band calling themselves The Plague cut their only single for the appropriately-named Epidemic Records (that was their only release as well), and consisted of former King Richards & The Knights drummer “Corky” Anderson along with Larry Shryock, Billy Main and Steve Erickson. Clearly, their “sound” was heavily influenced by the British Invasion band, The Kinks. Another group that recorded briefly for Delta was The Era Of Sound which included brothers Reynaldo and Michael Naranjo who also wrote both sides of their one release. Another one-release band were The Kreeg (guitarist/vocalist Robert J. Sturctman, lead guitarist Larry Ink, vocalist/bassist Hap Blackstock and drummer Russ Sturctman).

Compiled for Collectables by Michael Greisman, the full contents, showing artists, time lengths, label details and year of release, are: I Don’t Need You (1:52) - King Richard & The Knights - Delta 2143 - 1966; 2. review_headline: A GOOD BLUES SINGER/PIANO PLAYER/WRITER IN THE POST-WAR  CHICAGO STYLE WHO DESERVES TO BE BETTER KNOWN!
review_body:
This (67 1/2 minutes) album was recorded in 1968 in Switzerland at two different venues. Tracks 1-5 are previously unreleased (yes!) and tracks 6-17 were released on the Storyville label as "Eddie Boyd-Live". Boyd found Europe to his liking and moved there in the '60s, and this set has his first solo performances except for one previous track on the Sonet label. The sound is actually pretty good with a slight flatness to the sound--no doubt from the live recording techniques of the period. The booklet has an informative essay on Boyd and his music. This is somewhere between 3 and 4 "stars" but I 'm biased so I lean toward 4 "stars"--to each his own.

Boyd (a personal favorite) has a natural swing in his vocals and in his piano style. This set is a good example of authentic Chicago style piano blues. Many of these tunes are in a medium/up tempo shuffle mode with Boyd's vocals out front. He's best know for his song , "Five Long Years", which has become a blues classic, along with a couple of other tunes which are also here.

I first heard Boyd when he played with Peter Green and Fleetwood Mac way back in the late '60s. Once I heard his voice and his piano I was hooked. He recorded a couple of albums with Green, and a number of other English blues musicians that are well worth hearing. But his strongest work was done in the '50s-'60s for several labels in the Chicago area. Many of these sides have just been reissued ("Eddie Boyd Blue Monday Blues") and is a treasure chest of Chicago piano-based blues.

But on this set Boyd is all alone and sings many of his own compositions which highlight his lyrics and arranging skills. "Five Long Years" is here as is "Early In The Morning", "Third Degree", and other fine examples of his writing/playing/singing skills. If you've heard his late '60s work with Green you have some idea of how good a performer he is. And here all alone with his piano, there's no real low points--he knows the blues and how to communicate it to an audience.

Boyd never got the acclaim he should have during his hey-day except for his singles. And when the late '60s British blues era was popular he never really came to the attention of blues fans then either. and that's too bad. Boyd was a prime example of Chicago piano blues. His rolling, easy piano style and his knowing. pleading vocals, along with his song writing skills make him an unsung giant among Chicago blues piano performers. Sadly this review will reach only a few blues fans, but hopefully someone will hear Boyd and wonder how they missed hearing him until now.ere's no real low points--he knows the blues and how to communicate it to an audience. product_title: Wagner: Tristan Und Isolde. Nilsson," Windgassen; Bayreuth 1958
review_headline: A superb ""Tristan"" in good mono sound
review_body:
The obvious advantage to this 1957 recording in comparison to the more widely known and celebrated live recording from 1966 with the same two principals is that the singers are considerably younger. This applies particularly to Windgassen", who, while he never really had the necessary heroic ring to his tenor to qualify as an absolute Heldentenor, sang with such stamina, sensitivity and intelligence that before Jon Vickers arrived on the Bayreuth scene and after Vinay reverted to baritone, he established himself as the foremost Wagnerian tenor of his era. Here he is somewhat sappier, easier up top and less inclined to tire so we are hearing him at his considerable best. I am not so convinced that Nilsson is heard to advantage here compared with her more mature self; there are bald patches in the middle of her voice when she sounds rather plaintive and even a tad whiny but the laser top was already in full working order and her sheer volume and heft are things of wonder. She is immediately so impressive in her ravings, when she curses the ship she is travelling in and she launches her top notes fearlessly.

Some will also consider the presence in the pit of a young Sawallisch to present an advantage over the considerably more hectic and propulsive Karl Böhm in 1966. While I like the sheer excitement Böhm generates, Sawallisch creates more intensity and moulds phrases more tellingly; there is no lack of drive in the famous "Telegramme Duet" but his more leisurely approach is often preferable; hence this recording spills over onto four sides and begins with a swooning Prelude that lasts over twelve minutes. The orchestral playing is superb: sample the prelude in Act I to "Herr Tristan trete nah", where the progression of massive chords is so dramatic.

However, the supporting cast cannot measure up to that 1966, even if the little recorded but excellent tenor Walter Giesler is impressive as the Young Sailor and Fritz Uhl - later Nilsson's Tristan in a rather one-sided recording of the same opera under Solti - makes an impact as Melot. Grace Hoffmann is vocally very fine, her mezzo rich, steady and vibrant but her tone is also too often indistinguishable from that of Nilsson, whereas Christa Ludwig is a much more distinct character. Hans Hotter is grand but rather burly, effortful and a little clumsy as Kurwenal, sounding more grandfatherly, whereas Waechter is more the boyhood companion and retainer to Tristan. Arnold van Mill is grave noble and moving as King Mark but simply hasn't the vocal; depth and presence of Martti Talvela for Böhm; Talvela's Marke is simply shattering.

Finally there is the consideration of sound. Here it is good, clear mono with excellent balance between voices and orchestra even if the former is slightly too favoured but there is considerably more coughing and scraping of those wooden chairs and at first you would swear that a herd of rampaging elephants is still taking their seats as the first notes strike up. Fortunately things soon settle down and apart from the occasional intrusive hack in quiet moments such as when the lovers have drunk the potion and realisation is dawning, it remains very acceptable.

Thus, on balance, while I very much like this 1957 performance I do not actively prefer it to the later recording and I still turn to Vickers and Vinay for a more heroic Tristan.rather one-sided recording of the same opera under Solti - makes an impact as Melot. "A Better Place", less than two minutes but so close to his home that it brought me--a most agnostic type of person--close to tears. "Ghost On the Canvas" also stopped me short. Again, not a spiritual person but the line "they can't see souls" gave me pause to rethink. The rest of the album is a thoughtful and insightful look into who Glen Campbell is, was where his path may lead....

product_title: Jeroen van Veen: Piano Music by Jeroen van Veen [Music CD]
review_body:
You’d be hard pressed to think of anyone who’s done more to promote contemporary piano composition, particularly that in the “minimalist” vein, than the Dutch performer, Jeroen Van Veen. His protean efforts have yielded a wide range of voluminous recordings, all expertly performed in an exciting range of styles.

It’s not surprising, then, that he’s used his encyclopedic knowledge to also create a 5-disc offering of his own compositions, all excellent and the whole collection a listening delight. While it’s hard to briefly comment on so many CD’s, suffice it to say that the first three discs are openly minimalist in their origins and are hypnotic in their appeal, some cuts meditative while others will want to make you get up and dance (yes, I did). The range is delicious, including some engaging uses of prepared pianos, carillon, tape and organ. The fourth disc takes off in some unexpected directions, including a fascinating essay on the four elements and one of my favorites, “Repeating History,” a thrilling mash-up of fragments of classical compositions to which minimalist music is indebted, knowingly or not, and all knitted together seamlessly with Van Veen’s compositional threads. The last CD is NLXL, inspired by the aerial photography of Holland by Karel Tomei. There’s a great video (viewable on YouTube) of Van Veen and his wife, Sandra, performing it with huge projections of the photos behind them. I find this format more effective for the piece and while the Van Veens use a wide range of interesting techniques to accompany their two pianos (including ambient sounds), some themes overstay their welcome a bit for me without the visuals.

So, a LOT of music to enjoy from a composer/performer of great passions and a lively imagination. Definitely worth exploring!

This applies particularly to Windgassen, who, while he never really had the necessary heroic ring to his tenor to qualify as an absolute Heldentenor, sang with such stamina, sensitivity and intelligence that before Jon Vickers arrived on the Bayreuth scene and after Vinay reverted to baritone, he established himself as the foremost Wagnerian tenor of his era. Here he is somewhat sappier, easier up top and less inclined to tire so we are hearing him at his considerable best. I am not so convinced that Nilsson is heard to advantage here compared with her more mature self; there are bald patches in the middle of her voice when she sounds rather plaintive and even a tad whiny but the laser top was already in full working order and her sheer volume and heft are things of wonder. She is immediately so impressive in her ravings, when she curses the ship she is travelling in and she launches her top notes fearlessly.

Some will also consider the presence in the pit of a young Sawallisch to present an advantage over the considerably more hectic and propulsive Karl Böhm in 1966. While I like the sheer excitement Böhm generates, Sawallisch creates more intensity and moulds phrases more tellingly; there is no lack of drive in the famous "Telegramme Duet" but his more leisurely approach is often preferable; hence this recording spills over onto four sides and begins with a swooning Prelude that lasts over twelve minutes. The orchestral playing is superb: sample the prelude in Act I to "Herr Tristan trete nah", where the progression of massive chords is so dramatic.

However, the supporting cast cannot measure up to that 1966, even if the little recorded but excellent tenor Walter Giesler is impressive as the Young Sailor and Fritz Uhl - later Nilsson's Tristan in a rather one-sided recording of the same opera under Solti - makes an impact as Melot. Grace Hoffmann is vocally very fine, her mezzo rich, steady and vibrant but her tone is also too often indistinguishable from that of Nilsson, whereas Christa Ludwig is a much more distinct character. Hans Hotter is grand but rather burly, effortful and a little clumsy as Kurwenal, sounding more grandfatherly, whereas Waechter is more the boyhood companion and retainer to Tristan. Arnold van Mill is grave noble and moving as King Mark but simply hasn't the vocal depth and presence of Martti Talvela for Böhm; Talvela's Marke is simply shattering.

Finally there is the consideration of sound. Here it is good, clear mono with excellent balance between voices and orchestra even if the former is slightly too favoured but there is considerably more coughing and scraping of those wooden chairs and at first you would swear that a herd of rampaging elephants is still taking their seats as the first notes strike up. Fortunately things soon settle down and apart from the occasional intrusive hack in quiet moments such as when the lovers have drunk the potion and realisation is dawning, it remains very acceptable.

Thus, on balance, while I very much like this 1957 performance I do not actively prefer it to the later recording and I still turn to Vickers and Vinay for a more heroic Tristan.rather one-sided recording of the same opera under Solti - makes an impact as Melot.
